node.contents:
Its mentioned in Javadocs that for, public static Class
<!--?--> forName(String className) : className - the fully qualified name of the desired class.

node.contents: In my main I have the following statement

astNode.text: In my main I have the following statement

node.contents: Class booki = Class.forName("Book");

astNode.text: Class booki = Class.forName("Book");

node.contents: which throws a java.lang.ClassNotFoundException exception

astNode.text: which throws a java.lang.ClassNotFoundException exception

node.contents: when I use the full path like Class booki = Class.forName("javatests.Book"); it is ok.

astNode.text: when I use the full path like Class booki = Class.forName("javatests.Book"); it is ok.

node.contents: The main class and the Book class are in the same package, I also tried using import static javatests.Book.*; but still it throws the exception if I don't set the full path javatests.Book. Can someone explain to me why?

astNode.text: The main class and the Book class are in the same package, I also tried using import static javatests.Book.*; but still it throws the exception if I don't set the full path javatests.Book. Can someone explain to me why?

node.contents: You always need a qualified class name unless it's inside the same package. If i define a class foo in my package i can call a method Class testClass = Class.forName("foo") , but i can't call Class testClass = Class.forName("SecureRandom"); even if I import SecureRandom. That's just how the function works. It probably has a shortcut where it tries to find things inside local packages, but doesn't do much behind that.

astNode.text: You always need a qualified class name unless it's inside the same package. If i define a class foo in my package i can call a method Class testClass = Class.forName("foo") , but i can't call Class testClass = Class.forName("SecureRandom"); even if I import SecureRandom. That's just how the function works. It probably has a shortcut where it tries to find things inside local packages, but doesn't do much behind that.

node.contents: Class.forName resolves a fully qualified class name to the class. Since a method does not know where it is called from neither the package of the calling class nor imports in the calling class play any role.

astNode.text: Class.forName resolves a fully qualified class name to the class. Since a method does not know where it is called from neither the package of the calling class nor imports in the calling class play any role.

node.contents: JLS provides the following description:

astNode.text: JLS provides the following description:

node.contents: Class lookup is always on behalf of a referencing class and is done through an instance of ClassLoader. Given the fully qualified name of a class, this method attempts to locate, load, and link the class.

astNode.text: Class lookup is always on behalf of a referencing class and is done through an instance of ClassLoader. Given the fully qualified name of a class, this method attempts to locate, load, and link the class.

node.contents: The JDK uses one instance of ClassLoader that searches the set of directory tree roots specified by the CLASSPATH environment variable; and obviously it is not aware of the place (package) it has been called. That is why it needs fully qualified name.

astNode.text: The JDK uses one instance of ClassLoader that searches the set of directory tree roots specified by the CLASSPATH environment variable; and obviously it is not aware of the place (package) it has been called. That is why it needs fully qualified name.

node.contents:
Firstly the Book class must be in the package javatests.
the JVM load the class by name,through the classpath. There is no class named "Book" in the classpath. So JVM give you a ClassNotFoundException when excuse Class.forName("Book"). But 'Class.forName("javatests.Book")' tells JVM the class named 'Book' is in package 'javatests'. So the JVM can find it and load it.

astNode.text:

the JVM load the class by name,through the classpath. There is no class named "Book" in the classpath. So JVM give you a ClassNotFoundException when excuse Class.forName("Book"). But 'Class.forName("javatests.Book")' tells JVM the class named 'Book' is in package 'javatests'. So the JVM can find it and load it.
